title: How to Recreate JEREMY SOMA’s Studio Lighting – Bare Bulb, Clip Lights & Contrast Control
description:
In this video, we break down the lighting style of Jeremy Soma, known for his bold portraits and carefully constructed use of contrast. His lighting often feels raw,  grainy deliberate, and pared-back with a strong use of dramatic clip lighting. Pockets of shadow play against areas of desaturation and block colour. 

Across a series of his shoots, I look at several approaches, including:

• Bare bulb lighting used to carve sharp shadows and add intensity to the frame
• Clip lights positioned for precise highlights and sculptural accents
• Softlight umbrellas used to wrap light subtly around the face
• Specular highlights from Deep silver Umbrellas and Octas
• Mixing Strobe/Studio with Constant LED lighting


Soma’s portraits often rely on intentional pockets rather than filling everything evenly, he lets areas fall off into darkness, then introduces simple light sources to shape form and direct attention. A lighting style that feels restrained but confident.

Overall I feel there is a solid base to work from here, but I also gotta put my hand up and say I didn't nail this one a 100% so its a learning and testing tool, not a THIS IS HOW :)

I begin the tutorial with a lighting diagram, and draw in some basic areas to look at helping you visualise the spatial layout and understand how each light interacts. You’ll also see several variations for each setup, giving you practical options to recreate the look in your own studio.

If you’re looking to create stripped-back portraits with strong presence, this is a great reference.

title: How to Light a Fashion Campaign – 6 Look Studio Tutorial Inspired by Bershka
description:
If you're starting to shoot fashion content or want to build skills that actually get you booked this breakdown is for you.

I’ve recreated a lighting style based on a recent Bershka campaign to show how you can light six different looks in one efficient studio setup. It’s not about copying but it's about learning how to think like a campaign shooter and make creative decisions fast.

You’ll see how I structured the session to:

Keep the lighting adaptable but consistent across looks
Handle both skin and fabric tones cleanly under studio conditions
Make the most of one set while still giving variety
Mix editorial style with real eCom requirements
Allow easy set-ups so Video teams can also work easily

If you want to get work in this space, knowing how to light efficiently is a must.
Brands and clients need people who can deliver strong results without wasting time or overcomplicating the shoot. It’s one of those underrated skills that keeps clients coming back and helps you build a sustainable practice.

Whether you're working on your first eCom job or already shooting campaigns, this has loads you can take straight into your next session.

All references to Bershka are for educational use only. This is not an ad or collab I’m using the campaign as a visual case study for studio lighting and content creation. This is also not advocating fast fashion.

title: Petra Collins - 5 Key Elements of her Visual World
description:
If you're figuring out your visual identity as a photographer or creative, Petra Collins is someone worth studying. She doesn’t just take photographs she builds a world that feels soft, nostalgic, and a bit surreal, like a memory you didn’t know you had.

This breakdown looks at how she does it not through complex lighting or gear, but through repeated, intentional choices that give her work that emotional pull.

We break down how she uses:

Windows and blinds for layered framing

Colour that floods the entire image

Harsh front light and lens flares

Consistency across sets, styling, and composition

It’s not about copying her style it’s about understanding how to build your own. Because having a clear visual world is one of the most powerful things you can do as a photographer, art director, or stylist.

If you're trying to build a portfolio that actually stands out, this kind of visual thinking is what makes the difference.
Clients and collaborators respond to clarity and when your work feels like a world, people want to step into it.

All imagery shown is copyright Petra Collins (https://petra-collins.com), used here for educational and critical discussion.

title: Philip-Lorca diCorcia EXPLAINED – How He Blurred Truth & Fiction in Photography
description:
Discover how Philip-Lorca diCorcia used carefully constructed scenes to create photographs that feel both documentary and fictional. This video explores how his approach to staging, lighting, and subject matter challenged traditional ideas of authenticity in photography.

We examine diCorcia’s most important series including Hustlers, Heads, W Magazine, and East of Eden. From his earliest work, diCorcia showed an interest in performance, morality, and narrative tension. From using hidden strobes on the street to building cinematic fashion sets, his work pushed the limits of our perception of photography. 

Philip-Lorca diCorcia built his reputation as one of the most distinctive voices in 1990s and early 2000s photography working in analogue film. His images feel cinematic, psychological, and sometimes unsettling, but always meticulously constructed. His iconic work navigated the tension between observation and orchestration.

I really hope if you are new to his work you enjoy the journey of discovery ahead!

all images used for educational purposes here are copyright Philip-Lorca diCorcia (unless stated as Winograd, Friedlander or Groover). 

You may need to hit pause for some of the captions, editing this was a lot!

For more reading on PLDC try
https://spruethmagers.com/artists/philip-lorca-dicorcia
https://www.moma.org/artists/7027-philip-lorca-dicorcia
https://americansuburbx.com/2015/08/philip-lorca-dicorcia-reflections-on-streetwork-1993-1997.html
https://www.icaboston.org/art/philip-lorca-dicorcia/igor/

title: Mastering BEAUTY Photography Lighting - How to Light Like JASON KIM
description:
Want to master beauty photography lighting? This tutorial looks at the work of NYC photographer Jason Kim. 

Showcasing his work we explain how to recreate them in your own studio, using either Strobe or Constant lighting. 

Jason Kim is one of the most sought after beauty photographers working today, known for his refined lighting, soft-yet-contrasty looks, and precise colour work. He has been commissioned by the likes of Vogue, Glamour, Allure, Elle, Dior, MAC, Fenty, Bobbi Brown, Tommy Hilfiger, and Michael Kors.

https://jasonkim.com/

 (all images here used for educational purposes only)

In this tutorial, we break down key lighting techniques used in his beauty photography, exploring how you can recreate similar results in your own shoots. We look at how to make this affordable with minimal lighting, and working up to more sophisticated lighting techniques.

title: How to Recreate CHARLIE DENIS’ Studio Lighting – Cinematic & Theatrical Portraits
description:
Charlie Denis’ photography merges the theatrical with the everyday, creating a visual tension between stylised glamour and casual realism. His portraits often feel like cinematic moments caught between performance and reality, and of course he is known for his work alongside Nadia Lee Cohen. 

In this tutorial, we break down how to recreate Charlie Denis’ signature studio lighting style, focusing on constant light,  with its old school cinematic style and theatricality.

You can view his work at https://www.instagram.com/charliedenis and https://charliedenis.com/

(This is an affiliate link, meaning I earn a small commission at no extra cost to you. I genuinely use this software all the time—it’s an incredible tool for planning studio lighting setups.)

There are 5 Set-ups in this video, including a SKIMS campaign shoot.
You’ll Learn:
How to work with a KEY Light and clip lighting to achieve Denis’ signature Style.
How to sculpt depth using hard light using Arri Lighting.
How to work with "hard" lighting to sculpt muscle and skin. 

What I’ll Show You:
How to introduce subtle colour shifts to add a cinematic undertone while maintaining a natural feel.
How to control contrast and depth using practical light sources, negative fill, and selective shaping.
How to create a feeling of ‘real-world theatricality’ through light placement, shadow control, and subject positioning.

title: How to Recreate HARLEY WEIR’s Studio Lighting – Soft Sunlight & Window Highlights
description:
Harley Weir’s early photography is known for its naturalistic, intimate aesthetic often evoking the soft glow of window light and the organic highlights of sunlight filtering into a space. 

In this tutorial, we break down how to recreate Harley Weir’s signature studio lighting style, focusing on soft, diffused light, window-like highlights, and atmospheric warmth.

You’ll learn:

How to simulate soft natural sunlight in a controlled studio environment.
The best light sources and modifiers for creating Weir’s signature glow.
How to use positioning and diffusion to achieve directional highlights.
The subtle techniques that enhance texture and skin tones in a naturalistic way.

In this breakdown, I’ll take you through exactly how to achieve that look in a controlled studio environment, using a mix of diffusion techniques, subtle highlights, and colour balancing.

What I’ll Show You:
How to feather light to create gentle, natural-looking transitions between highlights and shadows.
How to use diffusion panels and polyboards to soften harsh sources and replicate sunlight.
How to introduce controlled colour shifts through gels and reflectors to add depth and warmth.
How to craft window-like light patterns with gobo projectors and staggered flags for a realistic sunlight effect.
How to balance contrast and shape using negative fill, accent lights, and selective highlighting.

Weir’s lighting is often delicate and directional, with highlights falling in controlled, painterly ways. I’ll walk you through each step, so you can replicate this aesthetic in your own shoots—even if you don’t have access to a big daylight studio.

Harley Weir’s approach blends painterly composition with a documentary-like softness, often working with large diffused sources to mimic the qualities of daylight. 

Whether you’re a fan of her work or looking to refine your approach to natural-looking studio lighting, this breakdown gives you actionable techniques to incorporate into your own shoots.

We also cover how to work in the Studio with Gels for colour lighting, high and low key lighting, Beauty Dish, softlighting with Octas or Umbrellas. 

Struggling with lighting in a small studio? Learn how to maximise space, control lighting spill, and achieve professional-quality results with minimal gear.

title: Studio Lighting for Small Spaces – A Complete One Hour Portrait Photography Tutorial
description:
Learn how to set up professional studio lighting for portraits in small spaces—whether for home studios, commercial setups, or temporary locations. This one-hour tutorial covers lighting setups, key techniques, and essential gear for working in confined spaces.

Support the channel and enhance your lighting workflow—get 15% off Set-a-Light 3D with our exclusive code: EASYSTUDIOLIGHTING at www.studio-lighting.com/recommends/setalight3d 

This is an affiliate link, which means I earn a commission at no extra cost to you. I genuinely use this software all the time, and it’s an incredible tool for planning studio lighting setups.

In this comprehensive, hour-long tutorial, learn how to maximise your studio space for Creative Model and Portrait lighting setups. Whether you're working in a home studio, a basement, a compact commercial space, or a temporary setup, this video provides clear help to elevate your lighting game.

Here’s what we cover:

Multiple Set-ups for Small Spaces: Advice to make the most of limited room while keeping setups practical and effective.

Essential Equipment: A breakdown of some must-have gear for small studios, including Softlight Umbrellas, Octas, Beauty Dish and grids.

Lighting Techniques: Learn how to use key lights, fill lights, background lighting, and rim lights in a small space.

Balancing Light: Techniques for controlling spill light and managing shadows in confined setups.
Working with Gels : Gels can be a real help in a small space and we really dig into how this can be great to work with. 

If you have access to a shared space, or have built out a space at home or in a lock-up or garage this video will give you loads of ideas to work with.

title: PETER LINDBERGH: The Lighting Secrets Behind His Iconic Supermodel Portraits
description:
Peter Lindbergh redefined natural light portraiture, capturing raw emotion and timeless beauty with his Black Tent lighting technique. His work with 1990s supermodels like Christy Turlington, Naomi Campbell, and Cindy Crawford remains some of the most influential photography in fashion history.

In this video, we analyse key elements of Lindbergh’s lighting style, including:

Subtractive lighting (Black Tent) to reduce harsh sunlight for softer tones.
Using Arri lighting for subtle, controlled exposure balance.
Strobe techniques to enhance natural contrast while maintaining softness.
Managing midday vs. afternoon light for outdoor shoots.

While no setup can be replicated exactly, this breakdown provides practical insights into how photographers can adapt Lindbergh’s lighting approach for their own outdoor and studio shoots.

By the end of this tutorial, you’ll have a deeper understanding of natural light shaping and how to refine your editorial portrait photography.

GOATED The genius of Peter Lindbergh. 
FOR TIMESTAMPS SCROLL TO END

For me, this was a deeply personal project—Lindbergh’s work has always been a source of inspiration, and it’s been a fun  journey to study his techniques in such depth.

I hope this breakdown not only teaches you new skills but also gives you a fresh appreciation for the genius of Peter Lindbergh. Contains Archive Peter Lindbergh footage from various sources.

Note these are ai summarised Timestamps and may have errors, but may also be of use.

title: Studio Lighting : Mastering the Second Light for Portrait Photography
description:

title: Golden Hour & Flash Photography – The Secret to Bold, Sunlit Portraits
description:
Golden Hour is one of the most beautiful times to shoot portraits—but how do you control the light? This video breaks down the power of Golden Hour lighting and how Off-Camera Flash can help you shoot in intense sunlight.

Golden Hour is a dream time for portrait photographers, but many struggle to balance natural warmth with controlled exposure. This tutorial explores:

How top photographers like Tyler Mitchell, Jamie Hawkesworth, Nadine Ijewere, and Harley Weir use Golden Hour.
How Off-Camera Flash allows you to shoot in direct sun without losing detail.
Ewen Spencer’s approach to raw, energetic outdoor photography.
How to avoid overexposed backgrounds while keeping skin tones rich and natural.
Whether you’re shooting film or digital, Golden Hour can create cinematic, glowing portraits—but flash can be the key to controlling contrast and exposure.

By the end of this breakdown, you’ll have a better understanding of how to blend natural light with off-camera flash to create bold, atmospheric photography.

This short video gives some of the reasons why its so effective. 

Then part 2 looks at the power of using Off Camera Flash to shoot in intense sunlight. A lot of photographers worry about shooting in direct sun, but with good use of Flash techniques it can be the perfect time of day to work. This short looks at the work of Brit Icon Ewen Spencer. 

I was recently asked to make my TikToks available to people who don't have the app, so this is what I am doing here. 

Maybe this single column format works better than the double, please let me know. 

1. Golden Hour 1.28min
2. Off Camera Flash 1.41min

#GoldenHourPhotography #OffCameraFlash #PortraitLighting #PhotographyTutorial #SunlitPortraits

title: Alex Prager & Nadia Lee Cohen – Cinematic Photography, Film Aesthetic & Narrative Influence
description:
Alex Prager and Nadia Lee Cohen craft striking cinematic photography inspired by classic Hollywood, surrealism, and carefully curated character-driven imagery. This deep dive explores their bold use of colour, light, and storytelling, revealing how film influences their photographic worlds.

Few photographers balance theatrical composition and cinematic storytelling as effectively as Alex Prager and the photographer she inspired, Nadia Lee Cohen. Their work exists in a space between fashion, portraiture, and narrative-driven imagery, evoking the feel of stills from an unknown film.

This video explores how Prager and Cohen use photography as a medium for visual storytelling, including:

Alex Prager’s Hitchcockian compositions and dramatic use of movement.
Nadia Lee Cohen’s hyper-stylised portraits, bold lighting, and surreal colour palettes.
How both artists draw inspiration from 70s Hollywood, David Lynch, and iconic directors.
The cinematic techniques they apply to photography, from framing to character styling.
We also examine how their work bridges the gap between film, photography, and fashion, influencing a new generation of image-makers.

By the end of this deep dive, you’ll gain insight into how these two photographers construct their distinctive, immersive visual worlds.

This is a compilation of my TikToks on Alex Prager and Nadia Lee Cohen.  

I saw Alex Pragers first London exhibition 2008 and fell in love with the work, it had a huge impact on some UK photographers including Nadia Lee Cohen. 

Nadia Lee Cohen, I take a look at her cinematic lighting and her use of narrative storytelling by taking the themes of directors she borrows heavily from in her early work. 

The video finishes with 20s of inspirational movie scenes or lighting. 

I was recently asked to make my TikToks available to people who don't have the app, so this is what I am doing here. 

I know its not the ideal layout and but I cant post longform Portrait format videos, so hopefully this isn't super annoying. If it is, dont send me bad vibes :)

1. Alex Prager 2.50min
2. Nadia Lee Cohen 3.30min
3. Film Inspiration 0.23min

title: Studio Lighting Tutorial : Recreating RAFAEL PAVAROTTI's British Vogue Cover Shoot
description:
Recreate Rafael Pavarotti’s British Vogue Lighting (with 3D Studio Lighting Simulations)
#StudioLighting #LightingTutorial #PhotographyLighting #RafaelPavarotti

In this video, we explore the lighting techniques used by Rafael Pavarotti for British Vogue’s stunning February 2022 shoot featuring Abény Nhial, Adut Akech, Akon Changkou, Amar Akway, Anok Yai, Janet Jumbo, Majesty Amare, Maty Fall, and Nyagua Ruea.

All images copyright British Vogue Feb 2022 and used for educational purposes only. 

Using Aputure lights and a compact studio setup, I demonstrate how to achieve a look inspired by Pavarotti’s work. Through detailed 3D lighting simulations, we’ll break down:

 - Key light placement and diffusion techniques.

 - Practical tips to adapt these techniques for your own creative shoots.

This tutorial isn’t a definitive guide but a starting point for photographers to explore and refine their understanding of studio lighting. Whether you're working with professional gear or simpler setups, this breakdown offers inspiration and workable ideas.

title: Capture One’s “Match Look” – Can One Click Really Recreate Any Style?
description:
Capture One just introduced "Match Look"—a one-click tool that lets photographers recreate the post-production style of any image. But how well does it actually work? In this video, I test it using a Jack Bridgland style low-res JPEG and an old TIFF file to see if it really holds up.

Capture One recently released Match Look, a new feature that allows photographers to instantly replicate the colour, contrast, and tonal characteristics of any reference image. This could be a game-changer for workflow efficiency, but what does it mean for photographers who have spent years refining their own distinct visual style?

In this video, I put Match Look to the test, experimenting with:

A Jack Bridgland low-res JPEG to see how it adapts to a high-contrast, bold aesthetic.
An older TIFF file to assess its accuracy on different formats.
The limitations and potential of this feature for real-world use.


I’ll be diving deeper into Match Look in a future video, but for now, here’s my first impression: It’s surprisingly effective even without further manual adjustment. But does it mean that signature editing styles can now be automated? There’s a lot to discuss.

#StudioLighting #CaptureOne #MatchLook #PhotographyEditing #PostProduction
